title: Occupational Therapy for Psoriatic Arthritis

content: For some years, I have had some of the most common (or “hallmark”) symptoms of psoriatic arthritis – swelling of the knuckles and the joints in the fingers. In my case, my left pointer finger has stiffened into a swan-neck appearance and my right thumb is descending. In order to maintain any grip to open bottles or door handles, I have sought the assistance of a specialist in strengthening and flexibility of the wrists and hands, an occupational therapist.
The following is some information you should know about occupational therapy for psoriatic arthritis:
Objectives of Occupational Therapy for PsA
Because psoriatic arthritis can adversely affect the joints in the fingers and hands, occupational therapy is intended to:
bullets: Assist with activities of daily life involving the hands, such as writing or typing, dressing, making meals, driving, household chores, or working.
Reduce the amount of stress placed on the joints in the hands, wrists, and fingers, and protection of the joints.
Recommend assistive devices to make manual tasks easier.
Produce splints or supports for the joints.
Recommend and provide instructions for exercise for range of motion and strength.

sections.heading: Preparing for Occupational Therapy
content: The principal characteristics of an occupational therapy practice for you to consider when choosing your therapist:

Check to see if the therapist is in your network of providers provided by your insurer. Find out the copayment and deductible for occupational therapy from your insurer. There may be limits on the covered number of visits in a year or other time period.
Initial Session

The occupational therapist will require a prescription from your physician that will indicate your diagnosis and suggested course of treatment. The physician will prescribe a course of therapy, which may include the focus of therapy services, timing of basic services, and then expansion of scope of services as the patient improves.

The initial session will probably be limited to an assessment by the occupational therapist. They will work from a checklist of questions, inquiring about your general health, the reason for your seeking therapy, the joints and fingers involved, areas of sensitivity, etc. Then they will use measurement devices to establish the baseline for your range of motion at the specific joints. They will ask you for your objectives in seeking occupational therapy, your goals, etc. For example, you may seek to return to writing, typing, or specific tasks for your employment (such as use of specific tools – screwdriver, hammer, wrench, etc.).
bullets: More than one occupational therapist at the location
Personal rapport with the therapist during the initial assessment

content: The occupational therapist should discuss the frequency of your visits, and they may discuss what they expect you to be doing between sessions (at home or work, stretching or exercises, and things you should not be doing for the time being).
Since their focus will be on your hands (and wrists), the occupational therapist will typically request that you wear a short-sleeved shirt or easily pushed-up long sleeves.
As a courtesy to others, some of whom may have allergies, do not wear strong deodorants or perfume.

You and the occupational therapist should talk about reasonable timetables for your goals, returning to work, activities, etc. You should discuss your goals and understanding of the time and effort that it may take to achieve them.

It is important to understand that your success in recovery and rehabilitation will be largely dependent on your cooperation and adherence to the guidelines provided by your physician and the occupational therapist.
First and Later Sessions
You will probably start with some warming device or hot towels for your hands, for perhaps 10 minutes.

content: Then the occupational therapist shall show you some simple stretching exercises for your hands and/or fingers.

Sometime after you have warmed up, the therapist will work on the areas that require attention, using stretching, massage, resistance devices, and the like, tailored to your specific needs and the status of your recovery and rehabilitation.

The therapist will demonstrate how an exercise is supposed to be done. They will watch you and will suggest how you can adjust your form in order to maximize the benefit of the exercise. Sometimes, you may be using a technique that does not maximize the intended benefit of the exercise.
After the first session, the therapist will ask how you are feeling and how well you felt and how long it took to recover from the last session.
Basic Understanding and Expectations
In order to make progress during your OT sessions, you need to understand and expect that you will experience the following:
bullets: You will be asked to perform some exercises that will test your limits. It will take time to fully recover, and the principal way to make progress is to push yourself beyond normal limits a little bit in each session.

You will discover that you will develop greater range of motion and strength over time. For example, you may be asked to do 10 repetitions three times for a particular exercise. Initially, you may be inclined to stop after the first 10, but you should try to do as many more before you are truly uncomfortable without harm. Push yourself a little.

You should let the therapist know when you believe that you have reached your limit, and they will modify their request, working with you to ensure that you continue to make progress without significant pain. Back in the days before masks, a grimace would work, but nowadays, tell them what you are feeling. This is not the time to be subtle or soft-spoken.

The therapist should let you know which exercises should be performed at home to enhance the recovery process; usually, doing hand exercises at least 15 to 20 minutes each day when you are not having a therapy session.

At the end of each session, the therapist will recommend that you have either a heating pad or cold pack applied to affected joints. Heating brings more blood to the area, and cold tends to decrease inflammation.

content: Establishing a rapport with your therapist, and thanking them for their efforts on your behalf, is always a good practice. You may need that person for future recoveries.
